calculation based\non the results from the application of a standard for intact stability that the\nintact stability of the vessel is appropriate. All calculations shall be\ncarried out free to trim and sinkage. The lightship data taken into account for\nthe stability calculation shall be determined by means of a heeling test.\n2.                      \nThe intact stability shall be proven for the\nfollowing standard load conditions:\n(a) at the start of the voyage:\n100 % passengers, 98 % fuel and fresh water, 10\n% waste water;\n(b) during the voyage:\n100 % passengers, 50 % fuel and fresh water, 50\n% waste water;\n(c) at the end of the voyage:\n100 % passengers, 10 % fuel and fresh water, 98\n% waste water;\n(d) unladen vessel:\nno passengers, 10 % fuel and fresh water, no\nwaste water.\nFor all standard load conditions, the ballast\ntanks shall be considered as either empty or full in accordance with normal\noperational conditions.\nIn addition, the requirement of section 3(d)\nshall be proved for the following load condition:\n100 % passengers, 50 % fuel and fresh water, 50\n% waste water, all other liquid (including ballast) tanks are considered filled\nto 50 %.\n3.                      \nThe proof of adequate intact stability by means\nof a calculation shall be produced using the following definitions for the\nintact stability and for the standard load conditions mentioned in paragraph\n2(a) to (d):\n(a)\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 the maximum righting lever hmax\nshall occur at a heeling angle of \u03c6max \u2265 (\u03c6mom\n+ 3\u00b0) and shall not be less than 0,20 m. However, in case \u03c6f\n< \u03c6max the righting lever at the downflooding angle \u03c6f\nshall not be less than 0,20 m;\n(b)\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 the downflooding angle \u03c6f\nshall not be less than (\u03c6mom + 3\u00b0);\n(c)\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 the area A under the curve of the\nrighting levers shall, depending on the position of \u03c6f and\n\u03c6max, reach at least the following values:\n Case ||   ||   || A \n 1 || \u03c6max \u2264 15\u00b0 or \u03c6f \u2264 15\u00b0 ||   || 0,05 m\u0387rad up to the smaller of the angles \u03c6max or \u03c6f \n 2 || 15\u00b0 < \u03c6max < 30\u00b0 || \u03c6max \u2264 \u03c6f || 0,035+0,001 \u0387 (30-\u03c6max) m\u0387rad up to the angle \u03c6max \n 3 || 15\u00b0 < \u03c6f < 30\u00b0 || \u03c6max > \u03c6f || 0,035+0,001 \u0387 (30-\u03c6f) m\u0387rad up to the angle \u03c6f \n 4 || \u03c6max \u2265 30\u00b0 and \u03c6f \u2265 30\u00b0 ||   || 0,035 m\u0387rad up to the angle \u03c6 = 30\u00b0 \nWhere:\n hmax ||   || is the maximum lever; \n \u03c6 ||   || the heeling angle; \n \u03c6f ||   || the downflooding angle, that is the heeling angle, at which openings in the hull, in the superstructure or deck houses which cannot be closed so as to be watertight, submerge; \n \u03c6mom ||   || the maximum heeling angle according to (e); \n \u03c6max ||   || the heeling angle at which the maximum righting lever occurs; \n A ||   || the area under the curve of the righting levers; \n(d)\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 the initial metacentric height, GMo,\ncorrected by the effect of the free surfaces in liquid tanks, shall not be less\nthan 0,15 m;\n(e)\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 in each of the following two cases the\nheeling angle \u03c6mom shall not exceed 12:\n(aa)\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 in application of the heeling moment\ndue to persons and wind according to sections 4 and 5;\n(bb)\u00a0\u00a0 in application of the heeling moment\ndue to persons and turning according to sections 4 and 6;\n(f)\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 for a heeling moment resulting from\nmoments due to persons, wind and turning according to paragraphs 4, 5 and 6,\nthe residual freeboard shall be not less than 0,20 m;\n(g)\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 for vessels with windows or other\nopenings in the hull located below the bulkhead decks and not closed watertight,\nthe residual safety clearance shall be at least 0,10 m on the application of\nthe three heeling moments resulting from subparagraph (f).\n4.                      \nThe heeling moment due to one-sided accumulation\nof persons shall be calculated according to the following formula:\n\u00a0[kNm\nwhere:\n P || = || total mass of persons on board in (t), calculated by adding up the maximum permitted number of passengers and the maximum number of shipboard personnel and crew under normal operating conditions, assuming an average mass per person of 0,075 t \n y || = || lateral distance of centre of gravity of total mass of persons P from centre line in (m) \n g || = || acceleration of gravity (g = 9,81 m/s2) \n Pi || = || mass of persons accumulated on area Ai in (t) \u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 Pi\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 =\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 ni \u0387 0,075 \u0387 Ai (t) \u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 where \u00a0\u00a0 Ai \u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 =\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 area occupied by persons in (m2) \u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 ni\u00a0\u00a0 =\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 number of persons per square meter \u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 ni \u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 3,75 for free deck areas and deck areas with movable furniture; for deck areas with fixed seating furniture such as benches, ni shall be calculated by assuming an area of 0,50 m in width and 0,75 m in seat depth per person \n yi || = || lateral distance of geometrical centre of area Ai from centre line in (m). \nThe calculation shall be carried out for an\naccumulation of persons both to starboard and to port.\nThe distribution of persons shall\ncorrespond to the most unfavourable one from the point of view of stability.\nCabins shall be assumed unoccupied for the calculation of the persons' moment.\nFor the calculation of the loading cases,\nthe centre of gravity of a person shall be taken as 1 m above the lowest point\nof the deck at 0,5 LWL, ignoring any deck curvature and assuming a\nmass of 0,075 t per person.\nA detailed calculation of deck areas which\nare occupied by persons may be dispensed with if the following values are used:\n P || = || \u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 1,1 \u0387 Fmax \u0387 0,075\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 for day trip vessels \u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 1,5 \u0387 Fmax \u0387 0,075\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 for cabin vessels where \u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 Fmax\u00a0\u00a0 =\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 maximum permitted number of passengers on board \n y || = || B/2 in (m). \n5.                      \nThe heeling moment due to wind pressure (MW)\nshall be calculated as follows:\nMW= pW \u2022 AW \u2022\n(lW + T/2) [kNm]\nwhere:\npW =\u00a0 the specific wind pressure of\n0.25 kN/m\u00b2;\nAW = lateral plane of the vessel\nabove the plane of draught according to theconsidered loading condition in\n[m\u00b2];\nlW =\u00a0\u00a0 distance of the centre of\ngravity of the lateral plane AW from the plane of draught according to the\nconsidered loading condition in [m].\nIn calculating the lateral plane, account shall\nbe taken of the intended enclosure of the deck by awnings and similar mobile\ninstallations\n6.                      \nThe moment due to centrifugal force (Mdr),\ncaused by the turning of the vessel, shall be calculated as follows:\nMdr = cdr \u0387 CB\n\u0387 v2 \u0387 D/LWL \u0387 (KG \u2014 T/2) (kNm)\nwhere\n cdr || = || a coefficient of 0,45; \n CB || = || block coefficient (if not known, taken as 1,0); \n v || = || maximum speed of the vessel in m/s; \n KG || = || distance between the centre of gravity and the keel line in m. \nFor passenger vessels with propulsion systems\naccording to Article 6.06, Mdr shall be derived from full-scale or\nmodel tests or else from corresponding calculations.\n7.                      \nThe applicant shall prove, by means of a\ncalculation based on the method of lost buoyancy, that the damaged stability of\nthe vessel is appropriate in the event of flooding. All calculations shall be\ncarried out free to trim and sinkage.\n8.                      \nBuoyancy of the vessel in the event of flooding\nshall be proven for the standard load conditions specified in paragraph 2.\nAccordingly, mathematical proof of sufficient stability shall be determined for\nthe three intermediate stages of flooding (25, 50 and 75 % of flood build-up)\nand for the final stage of flooding.\n9.                      \nPassenger vessels shall comply with the\none-compartment status and the two-compartment status.\nThe following assumptions concerning the\nextent of damage shall be taken into account in the event of flooding:\n   || 1-compartment status || 2-compartment status \n Dimension of the side damage ||   ||   \n longitudinal l [m] || 0,10 \u0387 LWL, however not less than 4,00 m || 0,05 \u0387 LWL, however not less than 2,25 m \n transverse b [m] || B/5 || 0,59 \n vertical h [m] || from vessel bottom to top without delimitation \n Dimension of the bottom damage ||   ||   \n longitudinal l [m] || 0,10 \u0387 LWL, however not less than 4,00 m || 0,05 \u0387 LWL, however not less than 2,25 m \n transverse b [m] || B/5 \n vertical h [m] || 0,59; pipework installed according to Article 15.02(13)(c), shall be deemed intact \n(a)\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 For\none-compartment status the bulkheads can be assumed to be intact if the\ndistance between two adjacent bulkheads is greater than the damage length.\nLongitudinal bulkheads at a distance of less than B/3 to the hull, measured\nperpendicular to the centre line from the shell plating at the maximum draft\nshall not be taken into account\nfor calculation purposes. A bulkhead recess in a transverse bulkhead that is longer than 2.50 m, is considered a\nlongitudinal bulkhead.\n(b)\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 For two-compartment status each\nbulkhead within the extent of damage will be assumed to be damaged. This means\nthat the position of the bulkheads shall be selected in such a way as to ensure\nthat the passenger vessel remains buoyant after flooding of two or more\nadjacent compartments in the longitudinal direction.\n(c)\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 The lowest point of every\nnon-watertight opening (e.g. doors, windows, access hatchways) shall lie at\nleast 0,10 m above the damaged waterline. The bulkhead deck shall not be\nimmersed in the final stage of flooding.\n(d)\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 Permeability is assumed to be 95 %. If\nit is proven by a calculation that the average permeability of any compartment\nis less than 95 %, the calculated value can be used instead.\nThe values to be adopted shall not be less\nthan:\n Lounges || 95 % \n Engine and boiler rooms || 85 % \n Luggage and store rooms || 75 % \n Double bottoms, fuel bunkers, ballast and other tanks, depending on whether, according to their intended purpose, they are to be assumed to be full or empty for the vessel floating at the plane of maximum draught || 0 or 95 % \n(e)\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 If damage of a smaller dimension than\nspecified above produces more detrimental effects with respect to heeling or\nloss of metacentric height, such damage shall be taken into account for\ncalculation purposes.\n10.                  \nFor all intermediate stages of flooding referred\nto in paragraph 8, the following criteria shall be met:\n(a)\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 the heeling angle \u03c6 at the\nequilibrium position of the intermediate stage in question shall not exceed\n15\u00b0;\n(b)\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 beyond the heel in the equilibrium\nposition of the intermediate stage in question, the positive part of the\nrighting lever curve shall display a righting lever value of GZ \u2265 0,02 m\nbefore the first unprotected opening becomes immersed or a heeling angle \u03c6\nof 25\u00b0 is reached;\n(c)\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 non-watertight openings shall not be\nimmersed before the heel in the equilibrium position of the intermediate stage\nin question has been reached;\n(d)\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 the calculation of the free surface\neffect in all intermediate stages of flooding shall be based on the gross\nsurface area of the damaged compartments.\n11.                  \nDuring the final stage of flooding, the\nfollowing criteria shall be met taking into account the heeling moment in\naccordance with paragraph 4:\n(a)\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 the heeling angle \u03c6E\nshall not exceed 10\u00b0;\n(b)\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 beyond the equilibrium position the\npositive part of the righting lever curve shall display a righting lever value\nof GZR \u2265 0,02 m with an area A \u2265 0,0025 m\u0387rad.\nThese minimum values for stability shall be met until the immersion of the\nfirst unprotected opening or in any case before reaching a heeling angle \u03c6m\nof 25\u00b0.\n\nWhere:\n \u03c6E ||   || is the heeling angle in the final stage of flooding taking into account the moment in accordance with section 4; \n \u03c6m ||   || is the angle of vanishing stability or the angle at which the first unprotected opening immerses or 25\u00b0; whichever is less is to be used; \n GZR ||   || is the remaining righting lever in the final stage of flooding taking into account the moment in accordance with section 4; \n GZK ||   || is the heeling lever resulting from the moment in accordance with section 4; \n(c)\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 non-watertight openings shall not be\nimmersed before the equilibrium position has been reached; if such openings are\nimmersed before this point, the rooms affording access are deemed to be flooded\nfor damaged stability calculation purposes.\n12.                  \nThe shut-off devices which shall be able to be\nclosed watertight shall be marked accordingly.\n13.                  \nIf cross-flood openings to reduce asymmetrical\nflooding are provided, they shall meet the following conditions:\n(a)\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 for the calculation of cross-flooding,\nIMO Resolution A.266 (VIII) shall be applied;\n(b)\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 they shall be self-acting;\n(c)\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 they shall not be equipped with\nshut-off devices;\n(d)\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 the total time allowed for\ncompensation shall not exceed 15 minutes.\nArticle 15.04\nSafety clearance and\nfreeboard\n1.                      \nThe safety clearance shall be at least equal to\nthe sum of:\n(a)\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 the additional lateral immersion,\nwhich, measured on the outside plating, is produced by the permissible heeling\nangle according to Article 15.03(3)(e), and\n(b)\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 the residual safety clearance\naccording to Article 15.03(3)(g).\nFor vessels without a bulkhead deck, the safety\nclearance shall be at least 500 mm.\n2.                      \nThe freeboard shall be at least equal to the sum\nof:\n(a)\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 the additional lateral immersion,\nwhich, measured on the outside plating, is produced by the heeling angle\naccording to Article 15.03(3)(e), and\n(b)\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 the residual freeboard according to\nArticle 15.03(3)(f).\nHowever, the freeboard shall be at least 300\nmm.\n3.                      \nThe plane of maximum draught is to be set so as\nto ensure compliance with the safety clearance according to paragraph 1, and\nthe freeboard according to paragraph 2 and Articles 15.02 and 15.03.\n4.                      \nFor safety reasons, the inspection body may\nstipulate a greater safety clearance or a greater freeboard.\nArticle 15.05\nMaximum permitted number\nof passengers\n1.                      \nThe inspection body shall set the maximum\npermitted number of passengers and shall enter this number on the Union inland\nnavigation certificate.\n2.                      \nThe maximum permitted number of passengers shall\nnot exceed any of the following values:\n(a)\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 number of passengers for whom the\nexistence of an evacuation area according to Article 15.06(8), has been proven;\n(b)\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 number of passengers that has been\ntaken into account for the stability calculation according to Article 15.03;\n(c)\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 number of available berths for\npassengers on cabin vessels used for voyages including overnight stays.\n3.                      \nFor cabin vessels which are also used as day\ntrip vessels, the number of passengers shall be calculated for use both as a\nday trip vessel and as a cabin vessel and entered on the Union inland\nnavigation certificate.\n4.                      \nThe maximum permitted number of passengers shall\nbe displayed on clearly legible and prominently positioned notices on board the\nvessel.\nArticle 15.06\nPassenger rooms and areas\n1.                      \nPassenger rooms shall:\n(a)\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 on all decks, be located aft of the\nlevel of the collision bulkhead and, if they are below the bulkhead deck,\nforward of the level of the aft-peak bulkhead, \n(b)\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 be separated from the engine and\nboiler rooms in a gas-tight manner, \n(c)\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 be so arranged, that sight lines in\naccordance with Article 7.02 do not pass through them.\nDeck areas which are enclosed by awnings or\nsimilar mobile installations not only above but also fully or partially to the\nside must satisfy the same requirements as enclosed passenger rooms.\n2.                      \nCupboards and rooms referred to in Article 11.13\nand intended for the storage of flammable liquids shall be outside the\npassenger area.\n3.                      \nThe number and width of the exits of passenger\nrooms shall comply with the following requirements:\n(a)\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 rooms or groups of rooms designed or\narranged for 30 or more passengers or including berths for 12 or more\npassengers shall have at least two exits. On day trip vessels one of these two\nexits can be replaced by two emergency exits; rooms, with the exception of\ncabins, and groups of rooms that have only one exit, shall have at least one\nemergency exit; \n(b)\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 if rooms are located below the\nbulkhead deck, one of the exits can be a watertight bulkhead door, according to\nArticle 15.02(10), leading into an adjacent compartment from which the upper\ndeck can be reached directly. The other exit shall lead directly or, if\npermitted in accordance with (a), as an emergency exit into the open air, or to\nthe bulkhead deck. This requirement does not apply to individual cabins;\n(c)\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 exits according to (a) and (b) shall\nbe suitably arranged and shall have a clear width of at least 0,80 m and also a\nclear height of at least 2,00 m. For doors of passenger cabins and other small\nrooms, the clear width can be reduced to 0,70 m;\n(d)\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 in the case of rooms or groups of\nrooms intended for more than 80 passengers the sum of the widths of all exits\nintended for passengers and which shall be used by them in an emergency shall\nbe at least 0,01 m per passenger;\n(e)\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 if the total width of the exits is\ndetermined by the number of passengers, the width of each exit shall be at\nleast 0,005 m per passenger;\n(f)\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 emergency exits shall have a shortest\nside at least 0,60 m long or a minimum diameter of 0,70 m. They shall open in\nthe direction of escape and be marked on both sides;\n(g)\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 exits of rooms intended for use by\npersons with reduced mobility shall have a clear width of at least 0,90 m.\nExits normally used for embarking and disembarking people with reduced mobility\nshall have a clear width of at least 1,50 m.\n4.                      \nDoors of passenger rooms shall comply with the\nfollowing requirements:\n(a)\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 with the exception of doors leading to\nconnecting corridors, they shall be capable of opening outwards or be\nconstructed as sliding doors;\n(b)\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 cabin doors shall be made in such a\nway that they can also be unlocked from the outside at any time;\n(c)\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 powered doors shall open easily in the\nevent of failure of the power supply to this mechanism;\n(d)\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 for doors intended for use by persons\nwith reduced mobility, there shall be from the direction from which the door\nopens, a minimum clearance of 0,60 m between the inner edge of the doorframe on\nthe lock side and an adjacent perpendicular wall.\n5.                      \nConnecting corridors shall comply with the\nfollowing requirements:\n(a)\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 they shall have a clear width of at\nleast 0,80 m. If they lead to rooms used by more than 80 passengers, they shall\ncomply with the provisions mentioned in (3)(d) and (e) regarding the width of\nthe exits leading to connecting corridors;\n(b)\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 their clear height shall be not less\nthan 2,00 m;\n(c)\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 connecting corridors intended for use\nby persons with reduced mobility shall have a clear width of 1,30 m. Connecting\ncorridors more than 1,50 m wide shall have handrails on either side;\n(d)\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 where a part of the vessel or a room\nintended for passengers is served by a single connecting corridor, the clear\nwidth thereof shall be at least 1,00 m;\n(e)\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 connecting corridors shall be free of\nsteps;\n(f)\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 they shall lead only to open decks,\nrooms or staircases;\n(g)\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 dead ends in connecting corridors\nshall be not longer than two meters.\n6.                      \nIn addition to the provisions of paragraph 5,\nescape routes shall also comply with the following requirements:\n(a)\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 stairways, exits and emergency exits\nshall be so disposed that, in the event of a fire in any given area, the other\nareas may be evacuated safely;\n(b)\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 the escape routes shall lead by the\nshortest route to evacuation areas according toparagraph 8;\n(c)\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 escape routes shall not lead through\nengine rooms or galleys;\n(d)\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 there shall be no rungs, ladders or\nthe like installed at any point along the escape routes;\n(e)\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 doors to escape routes shall be\nconstructed in such a way as not to reduce the minimum width of the escape\nroute referred to in paragraph 5(a) or (d);\n(f)\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 escape routes and emergency exits\nshall be clearly signed. The signs shall be lit by the emergency lighting\nsystem.\n7.                      \nEscape routes and emergency exits shall have a\nsuitable safety guidance system.\n8.                      \nFor all persons on board, there shall be muster\nareas available which satisfy the following requirements:\n(a)\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 the total area of the muster areas (AS)\nshall correspond to at least the following value:\n Day trip vessels || : || AS = 0,35 \u0387 Fmax (m2) \n Cabin vessels || : || AS = 0,45 \u0387 Fmax (m2) \nIn these formulae the following definition\napplies:\n Fmax ||   || maximum permitted number of passengers on board; \n(b)\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 each individual muster or evacuation\narea shall be larger than 10 m2;\n(c)\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 the muster areas shall be clear of\nfurniture, whether movable or fixed;\n(d)\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 if movable furniture is located in a\nroom in which muster areas are defined, it shall be secured appropriately to\navoid slipping;\n(e)\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 if fixed seats or benches are located\nin a room in which muster areas are defined the corresponding number of persons\nneed not be taken into account when calculating the total area of muster areas\naccording to (a). However, the number of persons for whom fixed seats or\nbenches in a certain room are taken into account must not exceed the number of\npersons for whom muster areas are available in this room;\n(f)\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 lifesaving appliances shall be easily\naccessible from the evacuation areas;\n(g)\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 it shall be possible to evacuate\npeople safely from these evacuation areas, using either side of the vessel;\n(h)\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 the muster areas shall lie above the\nmargin line;\n(i) the muster and evacuation areas are to be\nshown as such in the safety plan and signposted on board the vessel;\n(j)\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 the provisions of (d) and (e) shall\nalso apply to free decks on which muster areas are defined;\n(k)\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 if collective life-saving appliances\ncomplying with Article 15.09(5), are available on board, the number of persons\nfor whom such appliances are available may be disregarded when calculating the\ntotal surface area of the muster areas referred to in (a);\n(l)\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 however, in all cases where\nreductions according to (e), (j) and (k) are applied, the total area according\nto (a) shall be sufficient for at least 50 % of the maximum permitted number of\npassengers.\n9.                      \nStairs and their landings in the passenger areas\nshall comply with the following requirements:\n(a)\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 they shall be constructed in accordance\nwith European standard EN 13056: 2000;\n(b)\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 they shall have a clear width of at\nleast 0,80 m or, if they lead to connecting corridors or areas used by more\nthan 80 passengers, at least 0,01 m per passenger;\n(c)\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 they shall have a clear width of at least\n1,00 m if they provide the only means of access to a room intended for\npassengers;\n(d)\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 where there is not at least one\nstaircase on each side of the vessel in the same room, they shall lie in the\nsafe area;\n(e)\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 in addition, stairs intended for use\nby persons with reduced mobility shall comply with the following requirements:\n(aa)\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 The gradient of the stairs shall not\nexceed 38\u00b0;\n(bb)\u00a0\u00a0 The stairs shall have a clear width of\nat least 0,90 m;\n(cc)\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 Spiral staircases are not allowed;\n(dd)\u00a0\u00a0 The stairs shall not run in a direction\ntransverse to the vessel;\n(ee)\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 The handrails of the stairs shall\nextend approximately 0,30 m beyond the top and bottom of the stairs without\nrestricting traffic routes;\n(ff)\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 Handrails, front sides of at least\nthe first and the last step as well as the floor coverings at the ends of the\nstairs shall be colour highlighted.\nLifts intended for persons with reduced\nmobility, and lifting equipment, like stairlifts or lifting platforms, shall be\nconstructed according to a relevant standard or a regulation of a Member State.\n10.                  \nParts of the deck intended for passengers, and\nwhich are not enclosed, shall comply with the following requirements:\n(a)\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 they shall be surrounded by a fixed\nbulwark or guard rail at least 1,00 m high or a railing according to the\nEuropean standard EN 711: 1995, construction type PF, PG or PZ. Bulwarks and\nrailings of decks intended for use by persons with reduced mobility shall be at\nleast 1,10 m high;\n(b)\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 openings and equipment for embarking\nor disembarking and also openings for loading or unloading shall be such that\nthey can be secured and have a clear width of at least 1,00 m. Openings, used\nnormally for the embarking or disembarking of persons with reduced mobility,\nshall have a clear width of at least 1,50 m;\n(c)\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 if the openings and equipment for\nembarking or disembarking cannot be observed from the wheelhouse, optical or\nelectronic aids shall be provided;\n(d)\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 passengers sitting down shall not\ninterrupt sight lines in accordance with Article 7.02.\n11.                  \nThe parts of the vessel not intended for\npassengers, in particular access to the wheelhouse, to the winches and to the\nengine rooms, shall be such that they can be secured against unauthorised\nentry. At any such access, a symbol corresponding to Figure 1 in Appendix I\nshall be displayed in a prominent position.\n12.                  \nGangways shall be constructed in accordance with\nEuropean standard EN 14206: 2003. By way of derogation from Article\n10.02(2)(d), their length can be less than 4 m.\n13.                  \nTraffic areas intended for use by persons with\nreduced mobility shall have a clear width of 1,30 m and be free of doorsteps\nand sills more than 0,025 m high. Walls in traffic areas intended for use by\npersons with reduced mobility shall be equipped with handrails at a height of\n0,90 m above the floor.\n14.                  \nGlass doors and walls in traffic areas and also\nwindow panes shall be manufactured from pre-stressed glass or laminated glass.\nThey may also be made from a synthetic material, provided this is authorised\nfor use in a fire-protection context.\nTransparent doors and transparent walls\nextending as far as the floor in traffic areas shall be prominently marked.\n15.                  \nSuperstructures or their roofs consisting\ncompletely of panoramic panes and enclosures created by awnings or similar\nmobile installations and their substructures shall be so designed as to, and\nshall only be manufactured from materials which, in the event of an accident,\nreduce as much as possible the risks of injury to the persons on board.\n16.                  \nPotable water systems shall, at least, comply\nwith the requirements of Article 12.05.\n17.                  \nThere shall be toilets available for passengers.\nAt least one toilet shall be fitted for use by persons with reduced mobility\naccording to a relevant standard or a regulation of a Member State and shall be\naccessible from areas intended for use by persons with reduced mobility.\n18.                  \nCabins without an opening window shall be\nconnected to a ventilation system.\n19.                  \nBy analogy, rooms in which crew members or\nshipboard personnel are accommodated shall comply with the provisions of this\nArticle.\nArticle 15.07\nPropulsion system\nIn addition to the main propulsion system,\nvessels shall be equipped with a second independent propulsion system so as to\nensure that, in the event of a breakdown affecting the main propulsion system,\nthe vessel can continue to make steerageway under its own power.\nThe second independent propulsion system\nshall be placed in a separate engine room. If both engine rooms have common\npartitions, these shall be built according to Article 15.11 (2).\nArticle 15.08\nSafety devices and\nequipment\n1.                      \nAll passenger vessels shall have internal\ncommunication facilities according to Article 7.08. Such facilities shall also\nbe available in the operation rooms and, where there is no direct communication\nfrom the wheelhouse, in the access and muster areas for passengers as referred\nto in Article 15.06(8).\n2.                      \nAll passenger areas shall be reachable via a\nloudspeaker system. The system shall be designed in such a way as to ensure\nthat the information transmitted can be clearly distinguished from background\nnoise. Loudspeakers are optional where direct communication between the\nwheelhouse and the passenger area is possible.\n3.                      \nThe vessel shall be equipped with an alarm\nsystem. The system shall include:\n(a)\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 an alarm system enabling passengers,\ncrew members and shipboard personnel to alert the vessel's command and crew.\nThis alarm should be given only in areas\nassigned to the vessel's command and to the crew; it should only be possible\nfor the vessel's command to stop the alarm. The alarm shall be capable of being\ntriggered from at least the following places:\n(aa)\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 in each cabin;\n(bb)\u00a0\u00a0 in the corridors, lifts and stairwells,\nwith the distance to the nearest trigger not exceeding 10 m and with at least\none trigger per watertight compartment;\n(cc)\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 in lounges, dining rooms and similar recreation\nrooms;\n(dd)\u00a0\u00a0 in toilets, intended for use by persons\nwith reduced mobility;\n(ee)\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 in engine rooms, galleys and similar\nrooms where there is a fire risk;\n(ff)\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 in the cold-storage rooms and other\nstore rooms.\nThe alarm triggers shall be installed at a\nheight above the floor of 0,85 m to 1,10 m;\n(b)\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 an alarm system enabling the vessel's\ncommand to alert passengers.\nThis alarm shall be clearly and unmistakably\naudible in all rooms accessible to passengers. It shall be capable of being\ntriggered from the wheelhouse and from a location that is permanently staffed;\n(c)\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 an alarm system enabling the vessel's\ncommand to alert the crew and shipboard personnel.\nThe alarm system referred to in Article\n7.09(1), shall also reach the recreation rooms for the shipboard personnel, the\ncold-storage rooms and other store rooms.\nAlarm triggers shall be protected against\nunintentional use.\n4.                      \nEach watertight compartment shall be fitted with\na bilge level alarm.\n5.                      \nTwo motor-driven bilge pumps shall be provided.\n6.                      \nA bilge pumping system with permanently\ninstalled pipe work shall be available.\n7.                      \nCold-storage room doors, even when locked, shall\nalso be capable of being opened from the inside.\n8.                      \nWhere CO2 bar-systems are situated in rooms\nbelow deck these rooms shall be fitted with an automatic ventilation system\nwhich turns itself on automatically when the door or hatch to the room is\nopened. The ventilation ducts shall run down to 0,05 m from the floor of this\nroom.\n9.                      \nIn addition to the first-aid kit according to\nArticle 10.02(2)(f), further first-aid kits shall be provided in sufficient\nnumber. The first-aid kits and their storage shall comply with the requirements\nset out in Article 10.02(2)(f).\nArticle 15.09\nLife-saving equipment\n1.                      \nIn addition to the lifebuoys specified in\nArticle 10.05(1), all parts of the deck intended for passengers and not\nenclosed shall be equipped with suitable lifebuoys, which shall be positioned\non both sides of the vessel not more than 20 m apart. Lifebuoys shall be\nconsidered as suitable if they comply with\n\u2013              \nthe European standard EN 14144:2003, or\n\u2013              \nthe International Convention for the Safety of\nLife at Sea (SOLAS 1974) Chapter III Rule 7.1 and the International Life-Saving\nAppliance (LSA) Code, paragraph 2.1.\nHalf of all the prescribed lifebuoys shall be\nfitted with a buoyant cord at least 30 m long with a diameter of 8 to 11 mm.\nThe other half of the prescribed lifebuoys shall be fitted with a\nself-igniting, battery-powered light which will not be extinguished in water.\n2.                      \nIn addition to the lifebuoys referred to in section\n1, individual life-saving equipment according to Article 10.05, section 2,\nshall be within reach for all shipboard personnel. For shipboard personal not\nresponsible for undertaking duties according to the safety rota not inflatable\nor semi-automatically inflatable lifejackets according to the standards\nmentioned in Article 10.05, section 2, are allowed.\n3.                      \nPassenger vessels shall have appropriate\nequipment to enable persons to be transferred safely to shallow water, to the\nbank or to another craft.\n4.                      \nIn addition to the life-saving equipment\nreferred to in sections 1 and 2, individual life-saving equipment according to\nArticle 10.05, section 2, shall be available for 100 % of the maximum permitted\nnumber of passengers. Not inflatable or semi-automatically inflatable\nlifejackets according to the standards mentioned in Article 10.05, section 2,\nare also allowed.\n5.                      \nThe term \u2018collective life-saving equipment\u2019\ncovers ship's boats according to Article 10.04, and life rafts.\nLife rafts shall:\n(a)\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 bear a notice indicating their purpose\nand the number of persons for whom they are approved;\n(b)\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 offer adequate seating space for the\npermitted number of persons;\n(c)\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 provide a buoyancy of at least 750 N\nper person in fresh water;\n(d)\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 be provided with a rope linked to the\npassenger vessel to prevent them drifting away;\n(e)\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 be made of suitable materials and be\nresistant to oil, oil products and temperatures up to 50 \u00b0C;\n(f)\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 assume and maintain a stable trim\nand, in this respect, be fitted with appropriate devices enabling them to be\ngrabbed by the indicated number of persons;\n(g)\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 be fluorescent orange in colour or\nhave fluorescent surfaces, visible from all sides, of at least 100 cm2;\n(h)\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 be such that they can be released from\ntheir stowed position and put overboard quickly and safely by one person, or\ncan float free from their stowed position;\n(i)\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 be provided with appropriate means of\nevacuation from the evacuation areas referred to in Article 15.06(8), onto the\nlife rafts if the vertical distance between the deck of the evacuation areas\nand the plane of maximum draught is greater than 1 m.\n6.                      \nAdditional collective life-saving appliances are\nitems of life-saving equipment which ensure the buoyancy of several persons in\nthe water. These shall:\n(a)\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 bear a notice indicating their purpose\nand the number of persons for whom they are approved;\n(b)\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 provide a buoyancy of at least 100 N\nper person in fresh water;\n(c)\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 be made of suitable materials and be\nresistant to oil, oil products and to temperatures of up to 50 \u00b0C;\n(d)\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 assume and maintain a stable trim and,\nin this respect, be fitted with appropriate devices enabling them to be grabbed\nby the indicated number of persons;\n(e)\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 be fluorescent orange in colour or\nhave fluorescent surfaces, visible from all sides, of at least 100 cm2;\n(f)\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 be such that they can be released\nfrom their stowed position and put overboard quickly and safely by one person,\nor can float free from their stowed position.\n7.                      \nInflatable collective life-saving appliances\nshall in addition:\n(a)\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 comprise at least two separate air compartments;\n(b)\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 inflate automatically or by manual\ncommand when launched;\n(c)\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 assume and maintain a stable trim\nirrespective of the load to be supported, even when only half the air\ncompartments are inflated.\n8.                      \nThe life-saving appliances shall be stowed on board\nin such a way that they can be reached easily and safely when required.\nConcealed storage places shall be clearly marked.\n9.                      \nLife-saving equipment shall be checked according\nto the manufacturer's instructions.\n10.                  \nThe ship's boat shall be equipped with an engine\nand a searchlight.\n11.                  \nA suitable stretcher shall be available.\nArticle 15.10\nElectrical Equipment\n1.                      \nOnly electrical equipment shall be permitted for\nlighting.\n2.                      \nArticle 9.16(3), shall also apply additionally\nfor passageways and recreation rooms for passengers.\n3.                      \nFor the following rooms and locations, adequate\nlighting and emergency lighting shall be provided:\n(a)\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 locations where life-saving equipment\nis stored and where such equipment is normally prepared for use;\n(b)\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 escape routes, access for passengers,\nincluding gangways, entrances and exits, connecting corridors, lifts and\naccommodation area companionways, cabin areas and accommodation areas;\n(c)\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 markings on the escape routes and\nemergency exits;\n(d)\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 in other areas intended for use by\npersons with reduced mobility;\n(e)\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 operation rooms, engine rooms,\nsteering equipment rooms and their exits;\n(f)\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 wheelhouse;\n(g)\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 emergency power supply room;\n(h)\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 points at which extinguishers and fire\nextinguishing equipment controls are located;\n(i)\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 areas in which passengers, shipboard\npersonnel and crew muster in the event of danger.\n4.                      \nThere shall be an emergency power plant,\nconsisting of an emergency power source and emergency switchboard, which, in\nthe event of a failure of the supply to the following electrical equipment, can\nimmediately take over as their replacement supply, where the equipment does not\nhave its own power source:\n(a)\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 signal lights;\n(b)\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 audible warning devices;\n(c)\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 emergency lighting in accordance with\nparagraph 3;\n(d)\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 radiotelephone installations;\n(e)\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 alarm, loudspeaker and on-board\nmessage communications systems;\n(f)\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 searchlights according to Article\n10.02(2)(i);\n(g)\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 fire alarm system;\n(h)\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 other safety equipment such as\nautomatic pressurised sprinkler systems or fire extinguishing pumps;\n(i) lifts and lifting equipment within the\nmeaning of Article 15.06 (9), second sentence.\n5.                      \nThe light fittings for the emergency lighting\nshall be marked as such.\n6.                      \nThe emergency power plant shall be installed\noutside the main engine room, outside the rooms housing the power sources\nreferred to in Article 9.02(1), and outside the room where the main switchboard\nis located; it shall be separated from these rooms by partitions according to\nArticle 15.11(2).\nCables feeding the electrical installations in\nthe event of an emergency shall be installed and routed in such a way as to\nmaintain the continuity of supply of these installations in the event of fire\nor flooding. These cables shall never be routed through the main engine room,\ngalleys or rooms where the main power source and its connected equipment is\ninstalled, except insofar as it is necessary to provide emergency equipment in\nsuch areas.\nThe emergency power plant shall be installed\neither above the margin line or as far away as possible from the power sources\naccording to Article 9.02(1), so as to ensure that, in the event of flooding in\naccordance with Article 15.03(9), it is not flooded at the same time as these\npower sources.\n7.                      \nThe following are admissible for use as an\nemergency power source:\n(a)\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 auxiliary generator sets with their\nown independent fuel supply and independent cooling system which, in the event\nof a power failure, turn on and take over the supply of power within 30 seconds\nautomatically or, if they are located in the immediate vicinity of the\nwheelhouse or any other location permanently manned by crew members, can be\nturned on manually;, or\n(b)\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 accumulator batteries, which, in the\nevent of a power failure, turn on automatically or, if they are located in the\nimmediate vicinity of the wheelhouse or any other location permanently manned\nby crew members, can be turned on manually. They shall be capable of powering\nthe abovementioned power consumers throughout the prescribed period without\nrecharging and without an unacceptable voltage reduction.\n8.                      \nThe projected operating period for the emergency\npower supply is to be defined according to the defined purpose of the passenger\nvessel. It shall not be less than 30 minutes.\n9.                      \nThe insulation resistances and the earthing for\nelectrical systems shall be tested on the occasion of inspections according to\nArticle 2.09.\n10.                  \nThe power sources according to Article 9.02(1),\nshall be independent of each other.\n11.                  \nA failure of the main or emergency power\nequipment shall not mutually affect the operational safety of the\ninstallations.\nArticle 15.11\nFire protection\n1.                      \nThe suitability for fire protection of materials\nand components shall be established by an accredited test institution on the\nbasis of appropriate test methods.\n(a)\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 The test institution shall satisfy:\n(aa)\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 the Code for Fire Test Procedures; or\n(bb)\u00a0\u00a0 European standard EN ISO/IEC 17025:\n2000 concerning the general requirements for the competence of testing and\ncalibration laboratories.\n(b)\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 The recognised test methods for\ndetermining the non-flammability of materials are:\n(aa)\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 Annex 1, Part 1, of the Code for Fire\nTest Procedures; and\n(bb)\u00a0\u00a0 the equivalent regulations of one of\nthe Member States.\n(c)\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 The recognised test methods for\ndetermining that a material is flame-retardant are:\n(aa)\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 the respective requirements laid down\nin Annex 1, Parts 5 (Surface flammability test), 6 (Test for the deck\ncoverings), 7 (Test for hanging textiles and plastics), 8 (Test for upholstered\nfurniture) and 9 (Test for components of bedding) of the Code for Fire Test\nProcedures; and\n(bb)\u00a0\u00a0 the equivalent regulations of one of\nthe Member States.\n(d)\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 The recognised test methods for\ndetermining fire resistance are:\n(aa)\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 Annex I, part 3, of the Code for Fire\nTest Procedures, and\n(bb)\u00a0\u00a0 the equivalent regulations of one of\nthe Member States.\n(e)\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 The inspection body may, in accordance\nwith the Code for Fire Test Procedures, prescribe a test on a sample partition\nin order to ensure compliance with the provisions of paragraph 2 on resistivity\nand temperature increase.\n2.                      \nPartitions\n(a)\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 between rooms shall be designed in\naccordance with the following\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 tables:\n(aa)\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 Table for partitions between rooms, in\nwhich no pressurised sprinkler systems according to Article 10.03a are\ninstalled \n Rooms || Control centres || Stairwells || Muster areas || Lounges || Engine rooms || Galleys || Store rooms \n Control centres || - || A0 || A0/B151) || A30 || A60 || A60 || A30/A605) \n Stairwells ||   || - || A0 || A30 || A60 || A60 || A30 \n Muster areas ||   ||   || - || A30/B152) || A60 || A60 || A30/A605) \n Lounges ||   ||   ||   || -/A0/B153) || A60 || A60 || A30 \n Engine rooms ||   ||   ||   ||   || A60/A04) || A60 || A60 \n Galleys ||   ||   ||   ||   ||   || A0 || A30/B156) \n Store rooms ||   ||   ||   ||   ||   ||   || - \n(bb)\u00a0\u00a0 Table for partitions between rooms, in\nwhich pressurised sprinkler systems according to Article 10.03a are installed \n Rooms || Control centres || Stairwells || Muster areas || Lounges || Engine rooms || Galleys || Store rooms \n Control centres || - || A0 || A0/ B15 1) || A0 || A60 || A30 || A0/A305) \n Stairwells ||   || - || A0 || A0 || A60 || A30 || A0 \n Muster areas ||   ||   || - || A30/B15 2) || A60 || A30 || A0/A305) \n Lounges ||   ||   ||   || -/B15/ B 03) || A60 || A30 || A0 \n Engine rooms ||   ||   ||   ||   || A60/A0 4) || A60 || A60 \n Galleys ||   ||   ||   ||   ||   || - || A0/B156) \n Store rooms ||   ||   ||   ||   ||   ||   || - \n 1)\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 Partitions between control centres and internal muster areas shall correspond to Type A0, but external muster areas only to Type B15. \n 2)\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 Partitions between lounges and internal muster areas shall correspond to Type A30, but external muster areas only to Type B15. \n 3)\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 Partitions between cabins, partitions between cabins and corridors and vertical partitions separating lounges according to paragraph 10 shall comply with Type B15, for rooms fitted with pressurised sprinkler systems B0. Partitions between cabins and saunas shall comply with Type A0, for rooms fitted with pressurised sprinkler systems B15. \n 4)\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 Partitions between engine rooms according to Articles 15.07 and 15.10 (6) shall comply with Type A60; in other cases they shall comply with Type A0. \n 5)\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 Partitions between store rooms for the storage of flammable liquids and control centres and muster areas shall comply with Type A60, for rooms fitted with pressurised sprinkler systems A30. \n 6)\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 B15 is sufficient for partitions between galleys, on the one hand, and cold-storage rooms and food store rooms, on the other.\" \n(b)\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 Type A partitions are bulkheads, walls\nand decks which satisfy the following requirements:\n(aa)\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 They are made of steel or of another\nequivalent material;\n(bb)\u00a0\u00a0 They are appropriately stiffened;\n(cc)\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 They are insulated with an approved\nnon-combustible material such that the average temperature on the side facing\naway from the fire rises to not more than 140 \u00b0C above the initial temperature\nand at no point, including the gaps at the joints, does a temperature increase\nof more than 180 \u00b0C above the initial temperature occur within the following\nspecified periods:\nType A60 \u2014 60 minutes\nType A30 \u2014 30 minutes\nType A0 \u2014 0 minutes;\n(dd)\u00a0\u00a0 they are constructed in such a way as\nto prevent the transmission of smoke and flames until the end of the one-hour\nnormal fire test;\n(c)\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 Type B partitions are bulkheads,\nwalls, decks, ceilings or facings that meet the following requirements:\n(aa)\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 they are made of an approved\nnon-combustible material. Furthermore, all materials used in the manufacture\nand assembly of partitions shall be non-combustible, except for the facing,\nwhich shall be at least flame retardant;\n(bb)\u00a0\u00a0 they demonstrate an insulation value\nsuch that the average temperature on the side facing away from the fire rises\nto not more than 140 \u00b0C above the initial temperature and at no point,\nincluding the gaps at the joints, does a temperature increase of more than 225\n\u00b0C above the initial temperature occur within the following specified periods:\nType B15 \u2014 15 minutes\nType B0 \u2014 0 minutes;\n(cc)\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 they are constructed in such a way as\nto prevent the transmission of flames until the end of the first half hour of\nthe normal fire test.\n3.                      \nPaints, lacquers and other surface treatment\nproducts as well as deck coverings used in rooms except engine rooms and store\nrooms shall be flame-retardant. Carpets, fabrics, curtains and other hanging\ntextile materials as well as upholstered furniture and components of bedding\nshall be flame-retardant if the rooms in which they are located are not\nequipped with a pressurised sprinkler system according to Article 10.03a.\n4.                      \nLounge ceilings and wall claddings, including\ntheir substructures, shall, where these lounges do not have a pressurised\nsprinkler system in accordance with Article 10.03a, be manufactured from\nnon-combustible materials with the exception of their surfaces, which shall be\nat least flame-retardant. The first sentence shall not apply to saunas.\n5.                      \nFurniture and fittings in lounges which serve as\nmuster areas shall, where the rooms do not have a pressurised sprinkler system\naccording to Article 10.03a, be manufactured from non-combustible materials.\n6.                      \nPaints, lacquers and other materials used on\nexposed internal areas shall not produce excessive amounts of smoke or toxic\nsubstances. This shall be proven in accordance with the Code for Fire Test\nProcedures.\n7.                      \nInsulation materials in lounges shall be\nnon-combustible. This does not apply to insulations used on coolant-carrying\npipes. The surfaces of the insulation materials used on these pipes shall be at\nleast flame-retardant.\n7a.\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 Awnings and similar mobile\ninstallations with which deck areas are fully or partially enclosed and their\nsubstructures shall be at least flame-retardant.\n8.                      \nDoors in partitions according to paragraph 2\nshall satisfy the following requirements:\n(a)\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 they shall satisfy the same requirements\nset out in paragraph 2 as the partitions themselves;\n(b)\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 they shall be self-closing in the case\nof doors in partition walls according toparagraph 10 or in the case of\nenclosures around engine rooms, galleys and stairwells;\n(c)\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 self-closing doors which remain open\nin normal operation shall be such that they can be closed from a location\npermanently manned by shipboard personnel or crew members; Once a door has been\nremotely closed, it shall be possible to reopen and close it safely on the\nspot;\n(d)\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 watertight doors according to Article\n15.02 need not be insulated.\n9.                      \nWalls according to paragraph 2 shall be\ncontinuous from deck to deck or end at continuous ceilings, which satisfy the\nsame requirements as referred to in paragraph 2.\n10.                  \nThe following passenger areas shall be divided\nby vertical partitions as referred to in paragraph 2:\n(a)\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 passenger areas with a total surface\narea of more than 800 m2;\n(b)\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 passenger areas in which there are\ncabins, at intervals of not more than 40 m.\nThe vertical partitions shall be smoke-tight\nunder normal operating conditions and shall be continuous from deck to deck.\n11.                  \nHollows above ceilings, beneath floors and\nbehind wall claddings shall be separated at intervals of not more than 14 m by\nnon-combustible draught stops which, even in the event of fire, provide an\neffective fireproof seal.\n12.                  \nStairs shall be made of steel or another\nequivalent non-combustible material.\n13.                  \nInternal stairs and lifts shall be encapsulated\nat all levels by walls according to paragraph 2. The following exceptions are\npermissible:\n(a)\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 a staircase connecting only two decks\ndoes not need to be encapsulated, if on one of the decks the staircase is\nenclosed according to paragraph 2;\n(b)\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 in a lounge, stairs need not be\nencapsulated if they are located entirely within the interior of this room, and\n(aa)\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 if this room extends over only two\ndecks, or\n(bb)\u00a0\u00a0 if there is a pressurised sprinkler\nsystem according to Article 10.03a installed in this room on all decks, this\nroom has a smoke extraction system according to paragraph 16 and the room has\naccess on all decks to a stairwell.\n14.                  \nVentilation systems and air supply systems shall\nsatisfy the following requirements:\n(a)\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 they shall be designed in such a way\nas to ensure that they themselves do not cause the spread of fire and smoke;\n(b)\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 openings for air intake and extraction\nand air supply systems shall be such that they can be closed off;\n(c)\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 ventilation ducts shall be made from\nsteel or an equivalent non-combustible material and be securely connected to\neach other and to the superstructure of the vessel;\n(d)\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 when ventilation ducts with a\ncross-section of more than 0,02 m2 are passed through partitions\naccording to paragraph 2 of Type A or partitions according to paragraph 10,\nthey shall be fitted with automatic fire dampers which can be operated from a\nlocation permanently manned by shipboard personnel or crew members;\n(e)\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 ventilation systems for galleys and\nengine rooms shall be separated from ventilation systems which supply other\nareas;\n(f)\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 air extraction ducts shall be\nprovided with lockable openings for inspection and cleaning. These openings\nshall be located close to the fire dampers;\n(g)\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 built-in ventilators shall be such\nthat they can be switched off from a central location outside the engine room.\n15.                  \nGalleys shall be fitted with ventilation systems\nand stoves with extractors. The air extraction ducts of the extractors shall\nsatisfy the requirements according to paragraph 14 and, additionally, be fitted\nwith manually operated fire dampers at the inlet openings.\n16.                  \nControl centres, stairwells and internal muster\nareas shall be fitted with natural or mechanical smoke extraction systems.\nSmoke extraction systems shall satisfy the following requirements:\n(a)\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 they shall offer sufficient capacity\nand reliability;\n(b)\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 they shall comply with the operating\nconditions for passenger vessels;\n(c)\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 if smoke extraction systems also serve\nas general ventilators for the rooms, this shall not hinder their function as\nsmoke extraction systems in the event of a fire;\n(d)\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 smoke extraction systems shall have a\nmanually operated triggering device;\n(e)\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 mechanical smoke extraction systems\nshall additionally be such that they can be operated from a location\npermanently manned by shipboard personnel or crew members;\n(f)\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 natural smoke extraction systems\nshall be fitted with an opening mechanism, operated either manually or by a\npower source inside the extraction system;\n(g)\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 manually operated triggering devices\nand opening mechanisms shall be accessible from inside or outside the room\nbeing protected.\n17.                  \nLounges not constantly supervised by shipboard\npersonnel or crew members, galleys, engine rooms and other rooms presenting a\nfire risk shall be connected to an appropriate fire alarm system. The existence\nof a fire and its exact whereabouts shall be automatically displayed at a\nlocation permanently manned by shipboard personnel or crew members.\nArticle 15.12\nFire-fighting\n1.                      \nIn addition to the portable extinguishers\naccording to Article 10.03, at least the following portable extinguishers shall\nbe available on board:\n(a)\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 one portable extinguisher for every\n120 m2 of gross floor area in passenger areas;\n(b)\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 one portable extinguisher per group of\n10 cabins, rounded upwards;\n(c)\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 one portable extinguisher in each\ngalley and in the vicinity of any room in which flammable liquids are stored or\nused. In galleys the extinguishing agent shall also be suitable for fighting\nfat fires.\nThese additional fire extinguishers shall meet\nthe requirements laid down in Article 10.03, paragraph 2, and be installed and\ndistributed on the vessel so that, in the event of a fire starting at any point\nand at any time, a fire extinguisher can be reached immediately. In every\ngalley and also in hairdressing salons and perfumeries, there shall be a fire\nblanket to hand.\n2.                      \nPassenger vessels shall be provided with a\nhydrant system consisting of:\n(a)\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 two motor-driven fire extinguishing\npumps of sufficient capacity, at least one of which is permanently installed;\n(b)\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 one fire extinguisher line with a\nsufficient number of hydrants with permanently connected fire hoses at least 20\nm in length and fitted with a nozzle capable of producing both a mist and a jet\nof water and incorporating a shut-off facility.\n3.                      \nHydrant systems shall be designed and\ndimensioned in such a way that:\n(a)\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 any point of the vessel can be reached\nfrom at least two hydrants in different places, each with a single hose length\nof not more than 20 m;\n(b)\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 the pressure at the hydrants is at\nleast 300 kPa; and\n(c)\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 on all decks a water jet length of at\nleast 6 m can be attained.\nIf a hydrant chest is provided, an\n\u2018extinguisher hose\u2019 symbol similar to that shown in Figure 5 in Appendix I, of\nat least 10 cm side length, shall be affixed to the outside of the chest.\n4.                      \nHydrant valves with screw threads or cocks shall\nbe such that they can be set so that each of the fire hoses can be separated\nand removed during operation of the fire extinguishing pumps.\n5.                      \nFire extinguisher hoses in the internal area\nshall be rolled up on an axially connected reel.\n6.                      \nMaterials for fire-fighting equipment shall\neither be heat-resistant or shall be suitably protected against failure to work\nwhen subjected to high temperatures.\n7.                      \nPipes and hydrants shall be arranged in such a\nway that the possibility of freezing is avoided.\n8.                      \nThe fire extinguishing pumps shall:\n(a)\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 be installed or housed in separate\nrooms;\n(b)\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 be such that they can be operated\nindependently of each other;\n(c)\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 each be capable, on all decks, of\nmaintaining the necessary pressure at the hydrants and achieving the requisite\nlength of water jet;\n(d)\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 be installed forward of the aft\nbulkhead.\nFire extinguishing pumps may also be used for\ngeneral purposes.\n9.                      \nEngine rooms shall be fitted with a permanently\nfitted fire extinguishing system according to Article 10.03b.\n10.                  \nOn cabin vessels there shall be:\n(a)\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 two self-contained breathing apparatus\nsets corresponding to European standard EN 137: 1993 with full-face masks\ncorresponding to European standard EN 136: 1998;\n(b)\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 two sets of equipment consisting of at\nleast a protective suit, helmet, boots, gloves, axe, crowbar, torch and\nsafety-line, and\n(c)\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 four smoke hoods.\nArticle 15.13\nSafety organisation\n1.                      \nA safety rota shall be provided on board\npassenger vessels. The safety rota describes the duties of the crew and the\nshipboard personnel in the following eventualities:\n(a) breakdown;\n(b) fire on board;\n(c) evacuation of passengers;\n(d) person overboard.\nSpecific safety measures for persons with\nreduced mobility shall be taken into consideration.\nThe crew members and shipboard personnel\ndesignated in the safety rota should be assigned their various duties,\ndepending on the posts they occupy. Special instructions to the crew shall\nensure that, in the event of danger, all doors and openings in the watertight\nbulkheads referred to in Article 15.02 will be hermetically closed immediately.\n2.                      \nThe safety rota includes a safety plan, in which\nat least the following are clearly and precisely designated:\n(a)\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 areas intended for use by persons with\nreduced mobility;\n(b)\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 escape routes, emergency exits and\nmuster and evacuation areas as referred to in Article 15.06(8);\n(c)\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 life-saving equipment and ship's\nboats;\n(d)\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 fire extinguishers and fire\nextinguishing and pressurised sprinkler systems;\n(e)\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 other safety equipment;\n(f)\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 the alarm system referred to in\nArticle 15.08(3)(a);\n(g)\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 the alarm system referred to in Article\n15.(3)(b) and (c);\n(h)\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 the bulkhead doors referred to in\nArticle 15.02(5), and the position of their controls, as well as the other\nopenings referred to in Article 15.02(9), (10) and (13), and Article 15.03(12);\n(i)\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 doors referred to in Article 15.11(8);\n(j)\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 fire dampers;\n(k)\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 fire alarm system;\n(l)\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 emergency power plant;\n(m)\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 ventilation system control units;\n(n)\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 shore connections;\n(o)\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 fuel line shut-offs;\n(p)\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 liquefied gas installations;\n(q) \u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 public address systems;\n(r) \u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 radiotelephone equipment;\n(s) \u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 first-aid kits.\n3.                      \nThe safety rota according to paragraph 1 and the\nsafety plan according to paragraph 2 shall:\n(a)\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 be duly stamped by the inspection\nbody, and\n(b)\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 be prominently displayed at an\nappropriate point on each deck.\n4.                      \nA code of conduct for passengers shall be posted\nup in each cabin and also a simplified safety plan containing only the\ninformation referred to in paragraph 2(a) to (f).\nThis code of conduct shall include at least:\n(a) designation of emergencies\n\u2013              \nfire,\n\u2013              \nflooding,\n\u2013              \ngeneral hazard;\n(b) description of the various alarm signals;\n(c) instructions concerning the following:\n\u2013              \nescape routes,\n\u2013              \nwhat to do,\n\u2013              \nneed to keep calm;\n(d) instructions concerning the following:\n\u2013              \nsmoking,\n\u2013              \nuse of fire and naked flame,\n\u2013              \nopening windows,\n\u2013              \nuse of certain items of equipment.\nThese details shall be posted up in Dutch,\nEnglish, French and German.\nArticle 15.14\nWaste water collection and\ndisposal facilities\n1.                      \nPassenger vessels shall be equipped with\ncollection tanks for domestic waste water in accordance with paragraph 2 of\nthis Article or appropriate on-board sewage treatment plants in accordance with\nChapter 14a.\n2.                      \nWaste water collection tanks shall have\nsufficient capacity. Tanks shall be fitted with a device to indicate their\ncontent level. There shall be on-board pumps and pipes for emptying the tanks,\nwhereby waste water can be passed from both sides of the vessel. It shall be\npossible to pass waste water from other vessels through.\nThe pipes shall be fitted with a discharge\nconnection according to European standard EN 1306: 1996.\nArticle 15.15\nDerogations for certain\npassenger vessels\n1.                      \nPassenger vessels authorised to carry up to a\nmaximum of 50 passengers and with a length LWL of not more than 25 m shall\nprove adequate stability after damage according to Article 15.03(7 to 13) or,\nas an alternative, prove that they comply with the following criteria after\nsymmetrical flooding: \n(a) the immersion of the vessel shall not\nexceed the margin line and\n(b) the metacentric height GMR\nshall not be less than 0,10 m.\nThe necessary residual buoyancy shall be\nassured through the appropriate choice of material used for the construction of\nthe hull or by means of highly cellular foam floats, solidly attached to the\nhull. In the case of vessels with a length of more than 15 m, residual buoyancy\ncan be ensured by a combination of floats and subdivision complying with the\n1-compartment status according to in Article 15.03.\n2.                      \nFor passenger vessels in accordance with\nparagraph1 the inspection body may permit minor derogations from the clear\nheight required in Article 15.06(3)(c) and paragraph 5(b). The derogation shall\nnot be more than 5 %. In the case of derogations the relevant parts shall be\nindicated by colour.\n3.                      \nBy way of derogation from Article 15.03(9),\npassenger vessels not exceeding 45 m in length and authorised to carry up to a\nmaximum of 250 passengers do not need to have two-compartment status.\n4.                      \n(Left void)\n5.                      \nThe inspection body may waive the application of\nArticle 10.04 in the case of passenger vessels authorised to carry up to a\nmaximum of 250 passengers and with a length LWL of not more than 25 m, provided\nthey are equipped with a platform, accessible from each side of the vessel,\ndirectly above the line of flotation, so as to enable persons to be recovered\nfrom the water. Passenger vessels may be equipped with a comparable\ninstallation, subject to the following conditions:\n(a)\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 one person alone shall be able to\noperate the installation;\n(b)\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 mobile installations are allowed;\n(c)\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 the installations shall be outside the\ndanger area of the propulsion systems; and\n(d)\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 effective communication shall be\npossible between the boatmaster and the person in charge of the installation.\n6.                      \nThe inspection body may waive the application of\nArticle 10.04 in the case of passenger vessels authorised to carry up to a\nmaximum of 600 passengers and with a length of not more than 45 m, provided\nthey are equipped with a platform according to paragraph 5, first sentence, or\nwith an equivalent installation according to paragraph 5, second sentence. In\naddition, the passenger vessel shall have:\n(a) a rudder propeller, a cycloidal propeller\nor a water jet as main propulsion, or\n(b) a main propulsion system with two\npropulsion units, or\n(c) a main propulsion system and a\nbow-thruster.\n7.                      \nBy way of derogation from Article 15.02(9),\npassenger vessels not exceeding 45 m in length and authorised to carry at most\na number of passengers corresponding to the length of the vessel in metres are\nallowed to have on board, in the passenger area, a manually controlled bulkhead\ndoor without remote control according to Article 15.02(5), if:\n(a)\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 the vessel has only one deck;\n(b)\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 this door is accessible directly from\nthe deck and is not more than 10 m away from the deck;\n(c)\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 the lower edge of the door opening\nlies at least 30 cm above the floor of the passenger area, and\n(d)\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 each of the compartments divided by\nthe door is fitted with a bilge level alarm.\n8.                      \nOn passenger vessels in accordance with\nparagraph 7, by way of derogation from Article 15.06(6)(c), one escape route\nmay lead through a galley, as long as there is a second escape route available.\n9.                      \nFor passenger vessels with a length not\nexceeding 45 m the following shall not apply: Article 15.01(2)(e), when the\nliquefied gas installations are fitted with appropriate alarm systems for CO\nconcentrations posing a health risk and for potentially explosive mixtures of\ngas and air.\n10.                  \nThe following provisions shall not apply to\npassenger vessels with a length LWL not exceeding 25 m: \n(a) Article 15.04(1), last sentence;\n(b) Article 15.06(6)(c), for the galleys, as\nlong as a second escape route is available;\n(c) Article 15.07.\n11.                  \nFor cabin vessels not exceeding 45 m in length,\nArticle 15.12(10), shall not apply, provided smoke-hoods in a number\ncorresponding to the number of berths are readily accessible in each cabin.\nCHAPTER 15a\nSPECIFIC REQUIREMENTS FOR PASSENGER SAILING VESSELS\nArticle 15a.01\nApplication of Part II\nIn addition to the provisions of Part II,\nthe requirements in this Chapter shall apply to passenger sailing vessels.\nArticle 15a.02\nExceptions for certain passenger\nsailing vessels\n1.                      \nFor passenger sailing vessels having an LWL not\nexceeding 45 m and a maximum permissible number of passengers not exceeding LWL\nin whole meters, the following provisions shall not apply:\n(a) Article 3.03(7), provided that anchors are\nnot transported in hawse pipes;\n(b) Article 10.02(2)(d), with regard to\nlength;\n(c) Article 15.08(3)(a);\n(d) Article 15.15(9)(a).\n2.                      \nBy way of derogation from paragraph1, the number\nof passengers may be raised to 1,5 times the LWL in whole meters, if sails,\nrigging and deck fittings so permit.\nArticle 15a.03\nStability requirements for\nvessels under sail\n1.                      \nFor the calculation of the heeling moment\naccording to Article 15.03(3), the furled sails shall be taken into account\nwhen determining the centre of gravity of the vessel.\n2.                      \nTaking into consideration all load conditions\naccording to Article 15.03(2), and using a standard arrangement of sails, the\nheeling moment caused by wind pressure shall not be so high as to exceed a\nheeling angle of 20\u00b0. At the same time\n(a) a constant wind pressure of 0,07 kN/m2\nshall be applied for the calculation,\n(b) the residual safety clearance shall be at\nleast 100 mm, and\n(c) the residual freeboard shall not be\nnegative.\n3.                      \nThe righting lever of static stability shall\n(a) reach its maximum value at a heeling angle\nof 25\u00b0 or over,\n(b) amount to at least 200 mm at a heeling\nangle of 30\u00b0 or over,\n(c) be positive at a heeling angle of up to\n60\u00b0.\n4.                      \nThe area under the righting lever curve shall\nnot be less than\n(a)\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 0,055 mrad up to 30\u00b0;\n(b)\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 0,09 mrad up to 40\u00b0 or at the angle at\nwhich an unprotected opening reaches the water surface and which is less than\n40\u00b0.\nBetween\n(c)\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 30\u00b0 and 40\u00b0, or\n(d)\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 30\u00b0 and the angle at which an\nunprotected opening reaches the water surface and which is less than 40\u00b0,\nthis area shall not be less than 0,03 mrad.\nArticle 15a.04\nShipbuilding and\nmechanical requirements\n1.                      \nBy way of derogation from Article 6.01(3), and\nArticle 9.01(3), the equipment must be designed for permanent lists of up to\n20\u00b0.\n2.                      \nBy way of derogation from Article 15.06(5)(a)\nand Article 15.06(9)(b), the inspection body may, in the case of passenger\nsailing vessels not more than 25 m long, authorise a clear width of less than\n800 mm for connecting corridors and companionways. However, the clear width\nshall be at least 600 mm.\n3.                      \nBy way of derogation from Article 15.06(10)(a),\nthe inspection body may, in specific cases, authorise the use of removable\nguard rails in areas where this is necessary for controlling the sails.\n4.                      \nWithin the meaning of Article 15.07, sails rank\nas a main propulsion system.\n5.                      \nBy way of derogation from Article 15.15(7)(c),\nthe height of the lower edge of the door opening may be reduced to 200 mm above\nthe floor of the passenger area. Once opened, the door shall close and lock\nautomatically.\n6.                      \nIf there is a possibility of the propeller\nidling while the vessel is under sail, any endangered parts of the propulsion\nsystem shall be protected against potential damage.\nArticle 15a.05\nRigging in general\n1.                      \nThe parts of the rigging shall be arranged in\nsuch a way as to prevent unacceptable chafing.\n2.                      \nIf a material other than wood is used or if\nspecial types of rigging are used, such a design shall guarantee equivalent\nlevels of safety with the dimensions and strength values laid down in this\nChapter. As evidence of the strength\n(a)\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 a strength calculation shall be\ncarried out, or\n(b)\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 confirmation of sufficient strength\nshall have been obtained from an approved classification society, or\n(c)\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0\u00a0 dimensioning shall be based on the\nprocedures set out in a recognised regulatory framework (e.g. Middendorf,\nKusk-Jensen).\nThe evidence shall be presented to the\ninspection body.\nArticle 15a.06\nMasts and spars in general\n1.                      \nAll spars shall be made of high-quality\nmaterial.\n2.                      \nWood for masts shall:\n(a) be free of knot concentrations;\n(b) be free of sapwood within the required\ndimensions;\n(c) as far as possible be straight-grained;\n(d) contain as little as possible twisted\ngrowth.\n3.                      \nIf the chosen timber is either pitch pine or\nOregon pine of quality level \u2018clear and better\u2019 the diameters in the tables\nreproduced in Articles 15a.07 to 15a.12 can be reduced by 5 %.\n4.                      \nIf the timbers used for masts, topmasts,\nyardarms, booms and bowsprits are not round in cross-section, such timbers must\nbe of equivalent strength.\n5.                      \nMast pedestals, mast trunks and fastenings on\ndeck, on floor-plates and on stem or stern shall be constructed in such a way\nthat they can either absorb the forces they are subjected to or transfer them\nto other connected parts of the structure.\n6.                      \nDepending on the stability of the vessel and the\nexternal forces it is subjected to and also the distribution of the available\nsail area, the inspection body may, on the basis of the dimensions laid down in\nArticles 15a.07 to 15a.12, allow reductions in the cross-sections of the spars\nand, where appropriate, of the rigging. Evidence shall be submitted in\naccordance with Article 15a.05(2).\n7.                      \nIf the vessel's period of oscillation/period of\nroll, in seconds, is less than three quarters of its breadth, in metres, the\ndimensions set out in Articles 15a.07 to 15a.12 shall be increased. Evidence\nshall be submitted in accordance with Article 15a.05(2).\n8.                      \nIn the tables reproduced in Articles 15a.07 to\n15a.12 and 15a.14, possible intermediate values shall be interpolated.\nArticle 15a.07\nSpecial provisions for\nmasts\n1.                      \nWooden masts shall meet the following minimum\nrequirements:\n Length[13] (m) || Diameter on deck (cm) || Diameter on the cross-tree (cm) || Diameter on the mast cap (cm) \n 10 || 20 || 17 || 15 \n 11 || 22 || 17 || 15 \n 12 || 24 || 19 || 17 \n 13 || 26 || 21 || 18 \n 14 || 28 || 23 || 19 \n 15 || 30 || 25 || 21 \n 16 || 32 || 26 || 22 \n 17 || 34 || 28 || 23 \n 18 || 36 || 29 || 24 \n 19 || 39 || 31 || 25 \n 20 || 41 || 33 || 26 \n 21 || 43 || 34 || 28 \n 22 || 44 || 35 || 29 \n 23 || 46 || 37 || 30 \n 24 || 49 || 39 || 32 \n 25 || 51 || 41 || 33 \nIf a mast has two yards, the diameters shall be\nincreased by at least 10 %.\nIf a mast has more than two yards, the\ndiameters shall be increased by at least 15 %.\nIn the case of masts fitted through the deck,\nthe diameter at the mast foot shall be at least 75 % of the diameter of the\nmast at deck level.\n2.                      \nMast
